Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 209C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter due to the ongoing custody proceedings between the parties for Ava Smith and pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 209C, Section 10(a).

M.G.L. Chapter 208, Section 28.proposition: Various Massachusetts statutes and relevant case law support the consideration of such changes in custody arrangements, including: M.G.L. Chapter 208, Section 28, Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), among others.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Various Massachusetts statutes and relevant case law support the consideration of such changes in custody arrangements, including: M.G.L. Chapter 208, Section 28, Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), among others.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Yannas is among the Massachusetts authorities supporting judicial consideration of changes in custody/relocation arrangements under relevant statutes. This opinion squarely interprets and applies G.L. c. 208, §§ 30 and 31 in the context of a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts, articulating the governing “real advantage”/best interests standard for such relocation decisions. Thus, it directly provides the kind of statutory- and case-law support the proposition describes.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin… Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Various Massachusetts statutes and relevant case law support the consideration of such changes in custody arrangements, including: M.G.L. Chapter 208, Section 28, Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), among others.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Massachusetts statutes and case law, including Mason v. Coleman, support consideration of changes in custody arrangements in the relocation context. Mason squarely interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the governing standard for removal when parents share joint legal and physical custody, explicitly tying removal decisions to the children’s best interests and to modification of the existing shared custody arrangement. Thus, it is correctly cited as authority that such statutory and case law frameworks support considering and adjusting custody arrangements when a parent seeks to relocate.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents… Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only ‘upon cause shown,’ meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests… Today we consider the appropriate standard where parents have joint physical and legal custody. We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below.”
